conclusion: Electromagnetic aircraft launch is the most advanced catapult technology for aircraft carriers, and China has reached the world's advanced level in this field. An interest group is conducting research on the design of an electromagnetic launch system.

The mover, used to propel a model aircraft, is insulated and fixed to the coil. The coil drives the mover, which can slide without friction on the horizontal rails. The coil is located in a radial magnetic field between the rails, where the magnitude of the magnetic flux density is B.

When switch S is connected to 1, the constant current source is connected to the coil. The mover starts from rest, accelerating the aircraft. When the aircraft reaches takeoff speed, it detaches from the mover. At this time, S is thrown to 2, connecting the fixed resistor R0. Simultaneously, a retraction force F is applied. Under the action of F and the magnetic force, the mover returns to its initial position and stops.
The v-t diagram of the mover from rest to return is shown in Figure (2). From time t1 to t3, F=(800-10v)N, and F is removed at t3.

It is known that the takeoff speed v1=80m/s, t1=1.5s, the number of turns of the coil is n=100, the circumference of each turn is l=1m, the mass of the aircraft is M=10kg, the total mass of the mover and coil is m=5kg, R0=9.5Î©, and B=0.1T. Air resistance and the effect of aircraft takeoff on the mover's velocity are negligible.

The image shows a setup for an electromagnetic launch system. A coil is placed in a radial magnetic field between two rails. The coil drives a mover, which can slide without friction on the rails. The system includes a constant current source, a switch S, and a resistor R0.
The v-t diagram illustrates the velocity of the mover over time, showing acceleration, constant speed, and deceleration phases.

premise: From the v-t diagram, the mover accelerates from t1 = 1.5 s to t2 at a constant acceleration a.
conclusion: The takeoff speed v1 = 80 m/s is reached at t2.

premise: The mover then travels at constant speed v1 from t2 to t3.
conclusion: After t3, the mover decelerates back to rest.

premise: The force F is given by F = (800 - 10v) N from t1 to t3.
conclusion: The magnetic force Fm is given by Fm = I B l n, where I is the current, B is the magnetic flux density, and l is the circumference of each turn.

premise: The magnetic force Fm is given by Fm = I B l n, where I is the current, B is the magnetic flux density, and l is the circumference of each turn.
conclusion: The total force F_total = F - Fm is applied to the mover.
